title: Before 5 August 2019, will the president submit to Congress a bill for implementation of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA)?
preds: No signs  it's even in a fit state to be submitted
White House reportedly not sending to congress before September 1st.
I believe Trump is out of time with this and will wanna save it for a campaign issue in the fall, so he’s likely to delay it as long as possible.
It seems highly unlikely at this point.

Not enough progress to meet the closing date.
The bill submission is hampered by rules that allow amendments after a limited period of time after the submission to Congress.
GOP more likely to withhold the submission until agreements on changes are negotiated, preventing the Dems from voting on amendments to the bill.

There is too much contention in congress right now, and the President is not encouraging bipartisanship so I doubt he'd feel confident enough to try getting his pet project through. But, this is a highly unpredictable personality so anything could happen.

Initial Impression: Just learning the site, so I'm calling this a practice question.  I extremized the crowd response for my answer.  That said, trump wants 2x rate cuts this summer and needs the fed to think the economy is weak to make it happen.  From tweeting to monetary policy decisions it looks like he wants the market to fall.  This could be for a hundred reasons or none at all, but I think he's keeping a few trump cards (ouch) so he can tank the economy enough to get his rate cuts but still be in control to bring it back up.  He's holding out on trade deals and still hasn't done anything with china (but isn't making news about it either).  Trump is letting the market forget ongoing disputes - or be distracted from them - allowing the market to correct back to a steady uptrend.  Now, if the S+P tanks, he can clear the way with china or finalize a deal with mexico (something Mexico has been bending over backward to do for awhile now) and bump the market as though it was returning to normalcy instead fo becoming overinflated.  Give all the upcoming events in play (fed decisions, earning season for big players, trouble in the gulf, summer gas plays, election time, etc, etc) I don't think this will happen until after August 5th.  I think he wants to do this just +/- 3mo from the democratic primary so it's fresh in people's minds and can be used as leverage in the general election.  The mexico deal is just one of the dominos in his play for election season momentum and he won't play it until it's politically expedient

Implementation of the deal is currently not in Trumps interest therefore unlikely. Trump benefits from uncertainty in this field as it allows him Tom put pressure on Mexico in the border crisis. He can also use trade questions in his reelection ralleys.
I think Mr. President only wants to gain time

Not likely. Trump still has some fight in him. Although Mexico has been making the right noises, the most recent meeting where Trump came away & lied about getting some new concessions show that the 2 countries are still far apart from any agreement.

10 days to go. There's no evident reason to move any faster than the current September 1 deadline, and reports still indicate that not all issues within the Republican party have been ironed out.

Too many other distractions, and this does not feed his re-election agenda at this time.
Very unlikely in the short space of time left
Not much chance within this time frame. The budget process is a higher priority
The President id getting more  defensive

Free trade is a hallmark of the Democrats so even though this deal probably isn't as good for the US as NAFTA, I think at least enough Democrats to insure a majority can be swayed. The Republicans seem to be unable to handle Trump and will probably just vote in favour

US democrats unconvinced that labour laws are robust enough as part of USMCA. Encouraging talks about how the deal is critical from all 3 country leaders but US likely to stall progress momentarily due to internal political dissentions Trump/ Democrats.
Trump is stalling on this because he hopes that it will make him look good if he can get a deal very close to the election.

Political leverage would seem to be better for president to wait until closer to elections with the distractions and everything else going on can blame dems for not passing anything quickly and if economic depression it can all be because congress was too slow.

There are two main reasons for not doing this at this time. First, It is not a well-thought plan. Although it is NAFTA 2.0, it actually lacks in details compared to original deal. So, there are some details to iron out and that will take time considering President want to get it done at all. Second, President is not actively considering it in his usual agenda because he works based on what his supporting market is wishing at that point. At this point, there are other items in his plate as usual are more important to his supporters that he consider as priority.
Trump doesn't yet have the confidence to get it through Congress.

-Only 13 working days until the August recess (which begins the 8/5), so even if it is submitted it won't pass before then—especially given democratic opposition. It can still be ratified in September.

But Pelosi has also stonewalled previous trade deal processes in the past, so it is unlikely they submit it soon without her blessing.

https://thehill.com/homenews/house/451645-hopes-dim-for-passage-of-trump-trade-deal Hopes dim for passage of Trump trade deal
 07/05/19 "House Democrats say there's little to no chance that Congress will take up President Trump's replacement for the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) before the end of summer.  With only three more weeks scheduled to be in session before the August recess, House Democrats from across the spectrum are demanding that the trade pact with Mexico and Canada be renegotiated, citing concerns with the implications for labor and environmental standards as well as drug prices.  The Trump administration has been pushing for approval of the deal, known as the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), by August due to concerns that the 2020 presidential campaign will make it politically impossible to complete the deal this fall. Congress will also have to deal with avoiding a government shutdown and debt default after returning to Washington on Sept. 9 from the monthlong summer recess. But House Democrats say that the idea of getting the trade deal done by the end of the summer session is all but out of reach. “I don't see how that happens in three weeks,” said Rep. Earl Blumenauer (D-Ore.), chairman of the House Ways and Means trade subcommittee. As for the Trump administration’s push to get the trade pact through Congress by August, “That's their problem. We've told them what our interests are,” Blumenauer said. House Democrats insist that they do want to get the USMCA done, but aren't holding themselves to a deadline. Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) also downplayed the timing of 2020 politics, noting that U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer is still meeting with House Democrats to discuss their policy concerns. “[Lighthizer] frequently will say, ‘We just don't want to get this into the presidential.’ And I say, ‘These presidential candidates, there are 20, and I think most of them probably would want a better NAFTA.’ I certainly don't speak for them. But, that really doesn't have anything to do with — it's about the substance of the agreement, not the politics at all,” Pelosi said at a press conference before the House adjourned for the July 4 recess. “We do not want to pass this agreement just slightly different from NAFTA with a little sugar on top and say, ‘See, we did something different,’ ” she said. Most Democratic presidential candidates are calling for changes to the agreement along the same lines as House Democrats. Passing the USMCA would be a major legislative accomplishment for Trump as he campaigns for reelection next year. Despite their eagerness to see Trump out of office, Democrats say they want to replace the existing North American trade agreement. “As I say to the president, to the administration, you have leverage. We want to change NAFTA,” Pelosi said. “I think that's across the board that we do and everybody's working very hard to understand the differences, to try to eliminate some or prioritize as we go along. I'm hopeful that we'll be able to do something.” But the Trump administration, as well as the Canadian and Mexican governments, have been resistant to reopening the negotiations. Mexico became the first country to ratify the agreement last month, while Canada has yet to do so amid the uncertainty in the U.S. The White House pointed to Lighthizer’s talks with lawmakers when asked about the path forward to approve the USMCA this year given Democrats dismissing the odds of an August vote.  “The White House and USTR are working in good faith and constructively with members to address their concerns and Congress needs to approve USMCA, the best trade agreement ever negotiated, as soon as possible,” White House spokesman Judd Deere said. Lawmakers and some advocacy groups are starting to shift their expectations that the trade agreement could be approved in the next few weeks to possibly in the fall or the end of the year before 2020 actually arrives. They point to Pelosi designating nine House Democrats in mid-June to a working group to negotiate with the White House on changes to the North American trade deal and how Lighthizer is regularly meeting with lawmakers as a sign that an agreement could be reached in the coming months. “The reality is even if it doesn't get done before the August break, there's good momentum for it to be concluded in the fall,” said former Rep. Erik Paulsen (R-Minn.), an honorary co-chairman of the Pass USMCA Coalition who served on the House Ways and Means Committee. But Trade Works for America, another coalition advocating for approval of the USMCA, is still pushing for action by August. The group is running ads in 52 congressional districts across the country urging lawmakers to support the trade pact, including members of Democratic leadership.  “We do think the longer you slip into the political calendar, the more difficult an agreement like this is to pass,” said Marie Sanderson, senior adviser to Trade Works for America. “And certainly it becomes more complicated with the political and legislative calendar.” Sanderson also cited Pelosi’s appointment of a working group as a sign for optimism. “What we're doing is making sure that we create every opportunity for it to pass this summer,” Sanderson said, before acknowledging “the clock is ticking.” House Democrats are seeking stronger labor and environmental standards to prevent outsourcing to Mexico, as well as terms to rein in the cost of prescription drugs and ensure transparency for meat labeling. Before leaving for the July 4 recess, a group of 27 freshman House Democrats spanning the liberal and centrist wings of the party wrote a letter to Lighthizer demanding that the USMCA be renegotiated. “These improvements are necessary for a renegotiated NAFTA to obtain the broad support it needs to pass,” the Democrats wrote in the letter, spearheaded by Reps. Andy Levin (Mich.), Jesús García (Ill.) and Susan Wild (Pa.). The letter’s signatories included freshmen in districts carried by Trump in 2016, including Reps. Jefferson Van Drew (N.J.), Elaine Luria (Va.), Conor Lamb (Pa.), Jared Golden (Maine) and Elissa Slotkin (Mich.).  A number of freshmen who signed the letter, as well as some liberal members of the trade working group, also joined an event with AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka outside the Capitol a day earlier to demand changes to the USMCA. Levin, a member of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, dismissed the push to vote on the USMCA by August as an “artificial deadline.” But he maintained that House Democrats are sincere about reaching an agreement with the Trump administration. “I know Mr. Lighthizer feels pressure because he works with the president and the president wants to get it done. But we're working. We're really serious about getting to yes,” Levin said. “I don't care how long it takes,” Levin added. “If we can really get a real improvement for the people of my district in Michigan, I'm for it.”

With a lot changes occurring within the country and the President's interest in wanting to run for re-election, it seems less likely that it will be submitted before August. It is more likely that it will be submitted after August.
